As reported by Av Westin at the NET meetings in April, PBL began
this spring to experiment with some of the stations to use PBL
material as the core of locally produced broadcasts about community problems.
Six stations have received a print of an expanded version of the PBL report about
the O. I. C. job training for Negroes in ghetto areas. It's hoped stations can
launch an effort to supplement the PBL material with a locally produced program.
Problems and solutions to hard-core unemployment in the United States
were probed on "Help Wanted, " this month on two dozen stations of the Eastern
Educational Network with an audience potential of 33 million viewers. A teenager
(who is currently serving on the Security Patrol at Resurrection City), a man with
a police record in his later 20's and one over 45 related their experiences in
trying, and failing, to obtain work. They participated in a live, inter-city dis¬
cussion with three representatives of the National Alliance of Businessmen's
JOBS program. The program presented a realistic picture of the hard-core
unemployed, and found out what business is doing to alleveate the condition. The
90-minute broadcast was produced for EEN by WETA, Washington, D. C. , (with
assistance from WHYY, Philadelphia, and WNED, Buffalo) through a special grant
from the Carnegie Corporation.
Another EEN broadcast (90 minutes) featured teenagers from six metro¬
politan areas producing their own visual commentary on the cultural activities
of inner-city teenagers. "The Visual Generation" included the arts and doc¬
umentaries, and analysis of the films by the teenagers who talk about their work
with professionals. There was a drama on Negro life in Syracuse (WCNY) produced
by Youth Opportunity Unlimited; a color sound film about a teenager who becomes
a drug addict filmed by Mobilization for Youth (WNDT, New York); a concert by
the Oliver High School Entertainers in Pittsburgh (WOED); a photographic essay
on a Negro Ghetto in Allentown (WITF), a documentary on rural poverty by
teenagers from Orono, Maine (WMEB), and a film by the Mission Rebels showing
the work of San Francisco's (KQED) Performing Arts Workshop. The program
was produced for EEN by WCNY, Syracuse, with assistance from the other stations
mentioned.
On June 26, another ninety-minute special on EEN ("Talking Black") will
discuss the cultural and social aspects of the ghetto -- the cultural ties that do or
do not bind blacks in America's cities. Negro reporters in New York City (WNDT),
Boston, (WGBH) and Pittsburgh (WQED) will show filmed reports on the cultural
institutions in Harlem, Roxbury and the Hill, and will join in a discussion of their
inte r r elati on ship s.
